author: INbigE

description.text:
This is a spindle for the Home Depot cord reel. With some slight modification to the reel frame, it will hold a 5lb spool such as the one sold by UltiMachine.
This spindle has very low friction. I uploaded the original design and a version 2 design of the bottom piece that I thought would use less plastic. I checked the gcode generated for version 2 and it looks like it uses more plastic then version 1 using 25% fill. I have not yet printed the version 2 design. So let me know how it works if you decide to print it.

You have to remove the crank from the Home Depot cord reel by cutting or pinching the plastic opposite the crank. Then carefully stretch the frame and slide out the spool that it comes with. You have to cut off both of the sleeves sticking out on the inside of the frame. In a photo I show one of them removed. Now print one of the bottom, one of the top, and one bolt. The bolt was created using the great libraries from things http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9095 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8796.
For the cord reel check Home Depot for a Bayco 150 ft. 16/3 Cord Reel

comments.text: I just printed the V2 spindle on my Solidoodle and it worked fine. Â The spool alone weighed in at 80g of ABS and was one of the heftier things I've printed so far. Â The overall design works great though.Â  I was really surprised at how well the threads in the thumbscrew turned out - with absolutely no finishing required.

author: raystream

title: Spool holder for 8mm frame - for lazies

description.text:
I was looking for a spool mount for a 8mm acrylic frame with bearings. I did not find the thing I wanted so I designed my own. You need four standard 8x22x7 (608) bearings.
  • Super easy set up - 30 seconds of work for you :D
  • Uses four 608 bearings which are snap-mounted
  • No screws required
  • No threaded rods required
  • Snap-on guide pulleys
  • Easily adjustable spool width
  • For spools starting at 19cm diameter
  • Theoretically stable although not connected
  • Filament guide
    • Note: The fastening clips which hold the 8mm frame are quite short (14.5mm and 4.5mm) because of the LCD which blocks longer fastening features in my case. Thus, this mount is not tightly fixated. But you can of course mod the design to suit your needs Furthermore, this design may have higher friction than other bearing based mounts. Update
    Added v3 version. Uses only 2 bearings and offers no friction. However, it will only fit spools with a outer diameter of 200mm and below and a inner diameter of 57mm (Kiboplast). I have added STEP files if you like to change something. Check also: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1183634
Notes: Please select a proper printing orientation. The Files are not oriented correctly.

author: lukie80

title: Parametric pen holder for CNC
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a pen holder for your CNC. There is no moving parts (hence no mechanical play), no spring needed as it's the ABS part that is acting as a spring.
It's designed to be sturdy in X and Y direction but flexible in Z. It can be preloaded with a an ajustable screw (as seen in the photo between the bottom leg and the extruded aluminium).
I preloaded mine at 5 grams, that's enough to write with my pen, and thanks to this preloading I only need to move my Z axis by 0.3mm up and down to write and stop writing. But if you go further down it doesn't damage anything as the ABS part will bend and keep a moderate pressure on the pen.
I tried to go down 1mm after contact and the force increase from 5 to 10 grams. So you don't need to have a perfectly accurate machine to draw consistently.
OpenSCAD model included so you can adapt it to your machine.

title: Customizable generic fan guard / filter / mesh / bee's nest

description.text:
Just provide your own dimensions, mesh kind and cell sizes, height and so on. This thing should handle any fan size and fan guard requirements. I needed it because I broke twice the fragile fins of a 30 mm fan while it was on by waving a screwdriver around. Now it is safe.
Hey, you can even generate filters and bee's nests with it!
Nb: the last pic shows a blue Nylon version made by yzorg, where the raft itself is explicitly left in place for a finer filtering mesh (check the "make" section).

Some settings are a bit weird, especially the mesh_density_ratio, but it is useful to tune the mesh string size, so that your own printer and slicer do a good job. Else you may run in cases where your mesh cell walls are too thin for the nozzle at some places, which may generate messy printing paths. It think takes ages for the customizer to generate hex meshes with a 100mm+ fan, be patient or chose another mesh kind! My prints are quite dirty, because I used a raft with Nylon and no retraction (well, this really is trimming line: http://www.tridimake.com/2013/04/3D-printing-with-cheap-trimmer-line.html). I think it is still a good material, but a bit annoying to clean up sometimes!

comments.text: Neat design, though if you want to make a hex/square fan-guard and don't care if the corner parts are solid or not you can just make a square shape with the holes for the screws and an indented circle in the middle (to clear the fan blades) and then in slic3r set hexagonal infill and turn off top and bottom solid infills, gives you a fan guard with outer sides and holes joined by a hexagonal pattern. Since you're just using infill your slicer doesn't have to line up right with the model's widths etc. You can achieve that shape using this scad file by setting "mesh_holes_d=0;" btw.

remixed_from.title: functional rocket body tube with fins

title: Model Rocket Kit (nose+body w/ fins) for Engine D12-7

description.text:
light-weight sturdy model rocket that should be able to take the D12-7 rocket engine/motor easily and fly up high to the CUMULUS!!! include:
model for body tube w/ motor mount, center rings and fins;
model for quadratic shaped nose cone; max dimension: ~9" x 11("^2)

own an D12-7 motor;
print it with 3d printer directly if the dimension is allowed;
sand the upper edges of fins until smooth;
sand the connecting part of the nose cone until fits perfectly with body tube;
make a shock cord(rubber band) that is approx. length of body tube;
connect the nose cone and body tube with the shock cord by epoxy;
cut out a soft plastic parachute of about 8inch^2 area;
attach parachute with strings firmly;
tied the end of the strings to the middle of the shock cord;
add epoxy reinforcement at where ever you feel like so;
PAINT_DA_ROCKET;
squash anti-burn paper into the body tube from the top;
fold parachute nicely and put it into the body tube;
install the nose cone, make sure it's air tight;
ignite the rocket at an authorized/safe location, and weeeeeeeeeeee!

Variant chassis file for the incredibly well designed Arduino Drawing Robot made by MakersBox: http://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-Drawing-Robot/ I plan on using this in a class environment so I needed to get costs down as much as possible so I modified the design to be able to:
  • Use the mini breadboards we already have (will also accept any standard half board)
  • Use the battery packs we had on hand (2xAA and 3xAAA)
  • Use 5/8" bearing casters I found cheap

remixed_from.author: DKoss
remixed_from.title: I Build Ponies Hard Hat Insert

title: Customizable Hard Hat Inserts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE No. 5
Chatting with someone who has been customizing a lot of these I learned that they were further modifying the output with TinkerCAD. So I added a new tab "Non Hardhat Options" to add a button hole in the center of the tab, an option to add a counterweight and the ability to change the width (x) and length (y) of the tab. Changing any of these will likely make the tab unusable for hardhats.
I also took the chance to fix the error that was causing the CatchThemAll=0 to still "cast a net" for one catch. Now it actually recognizes a zero input. UPDATE No. 4
Okay. While I was in the file mucking around with the settings I tried a new way to catch abandoned geometry. Check out Ver5. Use the XT, YT boxes to move the "nets" to intersect the lost geometry and a nearby solid geometry. Use the XS, YS to change the "net" size. The script will add as many nets as you enter in the "CatchThemAll" variable. When generating the final STL the net will add a tab that's 1/3 the height of the font to connect the lost bits.
The downside is the massive amount of text entry boxes. On the plus side there are much fewer glitch artifacts compared to the other way. Does anyone know if there is a way for users to enter array's in customizer? What does everyone think of this modification? Is it easier? Ver4 is still available if you prefer that one. (I just tweaked Ver.5 to make the font spacing actually work and try to fix a rendering issue.) UPDATE No.3
Version 4 is up. Thanks to Lagger for the suggestion to make the clip and bottom a dynamic variable too.
I still don't like how the Orphan Control feature works. It creates too many glitches in other places. I have some new ideas for the orphan dots problem if I'm motivated to tackle that sometime. I just have to figure out how to show hidden geometry in the customizer window and not export it. UPDATE No2
Version 3 is up. The connection between lines above Line 1 are now two posts at about +/- one character width from center. Very few, very narrow characters (i,I,j,l.. etc.) will create problems. I don't think there will be many issues with it though. You may just have to work around it. I would like feed back though, is a full sized plate style connection better? Or the current two posts? I've tried to keep the two post going to the next available solid but not all the way to the previous base line. Is that creating problems? I've also further mimicked makkuro's name plate's handling of dots for i's and j's. There is a new parameter to adjust the sensitivity of the correction so to speak. If the dots aren't connecting then play around with the "OrphanSize". It works for now but I'd like to find a more elegant way of fixing it. Any suggestions? UPDATE No1
Version 2 is up. It's a different method for handling the bar across the bottom. Inspired by MC Geisler (thing:714444). That .SCAD file taught me not to forget about the intersection function. With that in mind version 2 still needs the i/j/!/? support bars. OriginalAfter a successful pony hardhat insert I copied my notes for the accessory slot tab into OpenSCAD and created an automated tab insert. In Customizer you can add up to 4 lines of text. I've updated the text quite a bit since first posting. The font spacing still handles a little funny. Each letter is given the same amount of space. But the connecting line (formally the "backer" option) is now automatic. Even with multiple rows of text. If you download the .scad then you can union with other .STL files. I'm new to OpenSCAD so please forgive my sloppy coding. Hopefully it makes at least a little sense and you can figure out how to use it. If you're looking for specific shapes like ponies for the STL then it helps to use a combination of Inkscape and TinkerCAD. I found a silhouette of a pony and imported it into Inkscape. Then used Path > Trace Bitmap > Edge Detection. Save the .SVG and load it into TinkerCAD to create the STL. Save as STL with the object centered on the X axis and positioned at 0 on the Y. Or adjust the "shiftx", "shifty" and "shiftz" variables as needed. (They just translate the STL file along respective axis'). The STL included was an STL combination from TinkerCAD while experimenting. It's still very much a work in progress so suggestions and tips are welcome!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Sometimes you have to use a bit force to snap the name badge, but that way it won't rotate.

comments.text: Yeah, I still don't know how to get that right. I just change the translate values (XT1 or YT1) to something crazy like 100. The code performs an intersection of the net with whatever it finds and then puts a hull() around it. So if there is no intersection then there is nothing to hull() and you won't (shouldn't) get any weird artifacts.

remixed_from.title: Model Rocket Kit (nose+body w/ fins) for Engine D12-7

title: Model Rocket Kit (nose+body w/ fins) for Engine C6-0

description.text:
light-weight sturdy model rocket that should be able to take the C6-0 rocket engine/motor easily and fly up high to the CUMULUS!!! include:
model for body tube w/ motor mount, center rings and fins;
model for quadratic shaped nose cone; max dimension: ~7" x 7("^2)

own an C6-0 motor;
print it with 3d printer directly if the dimension is allowed;
sand the upper edges of fins until smooth;
sand the connecting part of the nose cone until fits perfectly with body tube;
make a shock cord(rubber band) that is approx. length of body tube;
connect the nose cone and body tube with the shock cord by epoxy;
cut out a soft plastic parachute of about 8inch^2 area;
attach parachute with strings firmly;
tied the end of the strings to the middle of the shock cord;
add epoxy reinforcement at where ever you feel like so;
PAINT_DA_ROCKET;
squash anti-burn paper into the body tube from the top;
fold parachute nicely and put it into the body tube;
install the nose cone, make sure it's air tight;
ignite the rocket at an authorized/safe location, and weeeeeeeeeeee!

author: chev383

title: Agricola: All Creatures Big & Small Storage Tray

description.text:
This is a storage solution for the board game Agricola: All Creatures Big & Small. The border pieces are separated into 3 trays. Two "border trays" contains 9 borders, for each player, and a separate compartment in the "building tray" that holds the remaining 8 borders for replenishing the board each round. It fits all the pieces, including the two expansions in the box neatly. The "animal tray" is recessed 3mm so that you can store the score pad on-top, and the game board will sit flush keeping all the pieces in the compartments if you move it around. You'll need to print 1x each of the building, resource, and animal trays. And 2x border trays to make a full set. It's based on a foamcore solution posted on Board Game Geek by Colin Marsh:
https://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/111628/agricola-all-creatures-big-small-foamcore-solution
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1289331/agricola-acbs-expansions-foamcore-solution

title: Tarantula X6 adaptor for WLtoys Vibe mount

description.text:
Number 7 version. allows for mounting a Wltoys v262 style camera mount and battery under a Tarantula X6 so the battery adds weight to get rid of the jello in the cam that the Tarantula gets, without adding weight to the whole quad.
Mounting screw holes are still a tad large so screws pull right through.. nylon washers take care of that issue,.. otherwise it's a great fit and everything lines up.
will probably do a seven point X version and fix the screw holes as well as thinking of knocking out more in the holes to lighten up even more...

description.text:
Magnetic holder attached to a shelf. I created this thing to set my speaker under a shelf without using screws or any kind of adhesive, so no harm it's done to the shelf or the speaker. Also, the speaker can be oriented easily. But I think it can be used for more purposes.
I used a 5 cent Euro coin because it can be attracted to a magnet. You can find a magnet easily  inside a hard disk drive. Two magnets are enough to hold the speaker and can be hidden with the piece "cover". You also need two screws to attach the holder to the shelf.

author: chev383

title: Walkera Runner 250 Advance Battery Tray Upgrade

description.text:
I got tired of the cheap, poorly designed battery tray, so after messing around with it for the last time I just designed a brand new one.  This will hold your battery from ever smashing your OSD Module, and overall is easier to deal with.  Make sure you use the anti-slip mat, or strap the battery in good because it is slippery with the PLA I used.
I've included a file with the camera mount built in to save on screw, etc.  There are optional clamps to add with some screws that really stiffen up the whole frame and make flying a lot better and more responsive...

title: Raspberry Pi B+ and 7" Display Stand

description.text: This is a case and stand for the Raspberry Pi B+ and 7" Touch screen display.  The stand has an adjustable angle.

1x Raspberry Pi B+
1x 7" Touch Screen & Display board (I got mine from Element14 at http://au.element14.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/ProductDisplay?catalogId=15001&langId=43&urlRequestType=Base&partNumber=247387201&storeId=10184)
1x M4x16 screw
1x M4 nut
4x M3x8 screws
2x M3x10 self-tapping screws

• Attach the cover to the back of the Pi/Display using the 4 M3x8 screws - ensure that the cables are all comfortably tucked in.
  • Attach the bezel to the front of the Pi/Display by inserting the top of the display into the top of the bezel and then lock into position using 2 M3x10 self-tapping screws.
  • Insert the M4 nut into the back of the cover, insert the M4 screw into the bottom of the base so it pokes out the top, then screw together.
    • This is probably best printed in PLA unless you are good at keeping your ABS from warping. There are some pretty fine tolerances involved. Enjoy!

23/1/2016: Updated Rear.STL - M4 nut cavity was too small.
24/1/2016: Updated Rear.STL - moved some holes for connectors.
26/1/2016: Test print successful for Rear.STL and Stand.STL . Now printing Bezel to complete test.
28/1/2016: Test print successful - all the parts seem to fit together OK.

Future revisions may include the following:
  • Add hole for camera ribbon cable
  • Add mount for camera board
  • Add HDMI port and mounting for https://www.tindie.com/products/freto/pi-camera-hdmi-cable-extension/

Case for PINE A64 and A64+, the $15 64-Bit Single Board Super Computer - see the Kickstarter page for more information. Case consists of two parts, top and bottom. For the top there are two versions:
  • TOP-BATTERY has a dedicated holder for the add-on RCT CR battery holder.
  • TOP-GPIO has dedicated slots for the GPIO and other pins and on-board connectors.
    • The WiFi module fits with both versions. If you have no additional modules you can use either one. . I recommend putting rubber feet on the bottom to improve airflow. You can also use bolts longer than 20mm, as they can then act as legs (use additional nuts to avoid scratching the table), or print the vertical stand to position the case upright. UPDATE 2016-06-01, V4 I finally got my A64+; time for adjustments now that I can actually measure the little marvel! I have made a lot of improvements in this version, and I strongly recommend it over the previous versions that were entirely based on pre-production schematics and prototype photos. News in v4:
  • 25% smaller
  • Confirmed fit for WiFi module
  • Slide-in slot for RTC CR battery holder in the top part.
  • Slot for Power On button in the board default location
  • Slot for headset jack now support huge plugs
  • All additional slots optimized, including for GPIO pins in top part.
  • Standoffs fine-tuned to make sure they don't touch any board components
  • Reinforced edges, which helps prevent layer separation and flexing
  • Reinforced tabs
  • Optimized for 0.4 (or finer) nozzles - all walls are 1.6mm thick (4 x 0.4)
  • Better fit between top and bottom parts - the case can even stay together without any bolts & nuts, but I don't recommend tossing it in a bag without them.
  • Optimized for 20mm M3 bolts.
  • Slots for M3 nuts in bottom part, both regular and locking nuts work - leave a comment if you need a nut-less version as well (will require tapping the holes in the bottom part).
  • Port labels on inside of case. These will not be visible when assembled, but will clarify orientation of board.
    • UPDATE 2016-06-06, V4.1
    As requested, there is now a version available that has slots for both Power on and Reset buttons. Let me know how it works out! UPDATE 2016-06-07, V4.2
    Fixed the reset button slot which was too narrow, thanks for ed_co for pointing it out. This only affects the bottom part, and if you have already printed version 4.1 you can simply cut the bottom tab off to achieve the same effect. UPDATE 2016-08-22
    Added two versions of a vertical stand. Both are optional but may be useful for overclockers who want active cooling. STAND_FAN version have inserts for a 60mm fan on one side and a 40mm fan on the other. Unless pushing the board to the absolute limit there is no need for both.
    The cutouts in the stand matches the GPIO version, but it should work fine for the BATTERY version as well.

Printer:

RigidBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes: The case in the photos was a 0.2mm layer, 90mm/s print made on a heavily used glass bed without cleaning in between. Slower speed on a fresh bed will of course look much better.
It might be easier to fit the bolts if you first drill up the holes using a 3-4mm drill bit. Make sure the board is not in the case when doing this. :p

The PINE logo The PINE logo on the Kickstarter page and the technical specs is not quite symmetrical, has inconsistent distances between the various elements and a few other flawed details which I can only assume was unintentional on their side. In my version, everything is perfectly symmetrical with consistent geometrical distances and uniform angles. This version therefore differs slightly from the original, but for (in my opinion) the better.

comments.text: Any idea how much this weighs?  My local library has a 3D printer and they charge by the gram.  Just curious of the cost.  Thanks!
comments.author: jcroley

comments.text: It depends on the material you use, which version you are printing and what you set your infill ratio to. Using a 100% infill (which is overkill) with PLA, I think the total weight for the Bottom+Battery version lands around 60g. I don't know how much your library charge, but for me the material cost was less than 2€.
comments.author: jcroley

comments.text: Frank - Thanks.  This is just what I was looking for.  My library charges 10 cents per gram which puts me at a whopping $6 USD.  Well worth the price!
comments.author: FrankLumien

comments.text:
@FrankLumien, any chance of increasing the height of the case to accommodate a 7mm gap underneith the board? This would allow for heatsinks to be added to the underside RAM chips.(Not necessary, I realize, but hey, if you have them laying around, why not use them? xD)
Another thing I'd be interested in is mounting pins on the underside of the top section for a 40mm fan around the Pine logo. I don't know for sure whether the logo opening would accommodate pins in the requires spots, but perhaps it could be resized appropriately?
Lastly, I was hoping the bottom could be redesigned for straight line openings, rather than a large logo. This would not only increase the durability of the case, but also optimize airflow in the event that a fan is added. (the straight line openings in Thing:1428977 would be perfect)
comments.author: kronflux

comments.text:
@kronflux, interesting ideas. Instead of mounting the fan inside the case I made two vertical stands which you can now download. Just check the Files section - The description has also been updated. One of the stands has slots for external fans, and both versions matches the holes of the case perfectly. This was the best solution I could come up with without completely redoing the design of the top.
--Note to others: Feel free to remix the case to fit internal fans!--
FYI, my A64+ runs 24/7 and rarely gets more than lukewarm using this case (battery version). That is without stands, heatsinks or fans, just some rubber feet underneath. Are you doing some extreme overclocking, wanting both fans and heatsinks?
comments.author: kronflux

comments.text: 3 reasons behind it, first off being that I tend to be an extremist when it comes to cooling, so that alone feeds my desire for it, but I'm also planning on keeping one of my boards in a closet that gets extremely hot during the summer. lastly, I also got used to my raspberry pi setup which has heatsinks on every chip as well as a top mounted fan :P

comments.author: nonmindo

comments.text:
@nonmindo, sorry about the late answer. Unfortunately, I am hesitant to this idea. Partly as it would block airflow to the bottom of the board, partly because I don't know how warm the battery itself gets under full load. These two heat factors combined are not ideal.
Perhaps someone is willing to design @kronflux's idea above; a bottom attachment module for the battery? If I interpret his idea correctly, this would sit below the case itself, presumably with some shims of otherwise designed to allow airflow between the cases. Any takers?

comments.author: FrankLumien

comments.text: My previous suggestion should still work, let me clarify; Long bolt/screw => pine_a64_case_v3-TOP_SOCKETS => Board => pine_a64_case_v3-BOTTOM_SOCKETS => Enclosure => Nut. Or the other way around if you want to have the nut on the outside. This depends of course on how your enclosure looks, how you plan to mount the case to the enclosure, the dimensions of available space under the enclosure, or any other measurements to take into account.

author: moondoggie1968

title: xtrhdr a geared nema23 extruder for a cupcake

description.text:
This is an extruder for all the cupcake owners who have the wish for a stepper extruder and have some spare cheap nema 23 steppers.
Based upon the lovely extruder from Jag; Yet another extruder filament drive thing:7113.
It uses a makerbot MK5/MK6 filament drive gear, an extra stepperdriverboard, three 606 bearings and a variety of nuts 'n bolts. The goal was to use an old low torque stepper, the makerbot MK3 hotend (in the process replaced by something better..) and a lot of plastic. (aka no lasercuttted parts)
If you wonder why so much trouble, I wanted to make it so that you can re-use parts when upgrading to a real beefy stepper.
It has a support for an optional 2nd extruder, but that is needing some work.. if I'll ever do it.. It is being driven by the' experimental' stepperextruder setting from repg25, which works for me perfectly! I really don't know if anyone will build this thing, but when upgraded with a .35 nozzle for example from reprap-fab.org it prints actualy quite nicely for a makerbot from 2009.
With great help from the wobble arrester from twotimes and natetrue of course...

pick your hotend type, print out the parts nicely you'll need the strenght.
For the most obvious assembly, check the foto's.
To give the M3 bolts an extra grip,
I made them hot and pressed them into the plastic.

author: JaidynLChurch

title: Mount for BLTouch sensor on a Wombot

description.text:
This mount can be used to attach the BLTouch sensor to the Wombot extruder carriage.
The BLTouch sensor uses a hall effect device more details are here. https://plus.google.com/u/0/collection/8sQ5DB The arm attached to the extruder mount body with m3 x 10mm screws/nuts. The BLTouch attached to the arm with m2.5 x 10mm screws/nuts. The slot allow for quite a bit of initial adjustment due to the variances in mk8 extruders. See it in action on youtube https://youtu.be/B4yzOQo7iYY Note: This is not an official Wombot upgrade it is just alternative that I did for my own testing. The owner of the Wombot printer design is http://www.aurarum.com.au/

Printer:

Wombot Exilis

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50

These simple add-on parts are for use on a Prusa i3 with those "z-top" parts that have a hole, which may potentially allow the smooth rods to move up and down. Clipping these onto the "z-top" parts will prevent the smooth bars from moving.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: These print well in either PLA or ABS. Supports are built-in, so no need to add them.

These parts were made in OpenSCAD. You can customize the SCAD file to tailor them to your needs. The included STL files will be fine if your smooth bars are the perfect length, but you should set leftExtraSlot or rightExtraSlot if a bar sticks up above the Z top. To use the "ztopper_both_in_situ" option in the SCAD file, you will need to download and unzip the data.zip file in the same folder as the SCAD file. It contains a data folder with the z-top-left.stl file.

Dress up your X-wing miniatures game with 3 dimensional asteroids.  The files included are the stands needed to mount your custom asteroids.  There are two different styles of stands:  The first set is a close approximation of the six different asteroid pieces that come with the game (suitable when playing with rules lawyers).  The second set consists of large, medium, small, and tiny sized circular bases.
Once you print out the bases you'll need some asteroids.  You don't want to 3-D print your asteroids, instead use lava rocks commonly available for landscaping.  I picked mine up off the ground at a mini-golf course and a Home Depot parking lot.  Lava rocks are lighter than 'normal' rocks so the stands won't tip over easily and you can drill holes in them without too much trouble.  Finally, every rock is unique so the tabletop will look more realistic.
Paint the rocks with the cheapest black spray paint you can find and then drybrush them in progressively lighter shades of color.  I used dark gray -> light gray - > white for some of the rocks and brown -> tan -> bone white on the rest of them.  They look great with minimal effort.
Drill an 1/8" diameter hole in the rock and push it onto the stand.  You can also snap off a random length of each post so the rocks will be floating at different heights.
Happy gaming.

This file is a free download.  Since it is listed as 'creative commons - attribution' there are very few restrictions on how you use these files.  You are welcome (and encouraged) to print them out for yourself for personal use.  You are also allowed to buy and sell physical copies of the models.  However, if you use my files and my pictures you should provide a link back to where you got them. Thanks.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3l3gsPvw5u1

This is a small box and lid in a golf motif. It was scanned with the DAVID SLS-2 scanner and TT-1 turntable.
I recommend dropping the box about .3mm into the bed when slicing to simplify printing.
The lid should be dropped about 1mm into the bed before slicing. The lid will need supports around the perimeter.

comments.text: Botacer------- I made this and although its a great box and lid Ii could not keep them from warping and lifting on the bed. My printer will only get to 80 c  on the bed. I think i need at least 110 c
comments.author: botacer

comments.text: Did you drop the models into your bed before slicing in your software? After dropping the box and lid to the software bed surface, lower the parts an additional 0.3 mm into the software bed surface prior to slicing (usually a number below zero in the Z axis). The slicer will cut off the portions of the model below the software bed's surface and create a perfectly flat cross section that will adhere to the bed better later when you print the gcode. This model is a 3D scan and the actual box and lid are not perfectly flat, so it may pull off the bed if you try to print the model without lowering it in the software before slicing.
comments.author: botacer

comments.text: I assume you are printing with ABS? Can your printer print with PLA? That won't warp and you don't need a hot print bed. PETG won't warp either.
comments.author: botacer

title: V3 DJI Phantom Pitch Control Lever

description.text: V2 of very popular DJI Phantom Pitch Control Lever. We spent over a month perfecting the design and now its fully complete. It's super easy to start shooting amazing aerial videos in seconds. Just plug and play :) You can buy this part on ebay: http://www.ebay.com/itm/ws/181184174320 DJI Phantom transmitter has a hidden 7th channel which can be manipulated to control the pitch of the gimbal with 3d printable pitch control lever. Now you can comfortably adjust pitch position of your camera while flying your Phantom. This empowers you to do amazing aerial shots! 3d printable pitch control lever is attached at the back of the phantom transmitter and fits perfectly. Nothing extra is required! Designed by https://www.bustmold.com/ottawa/ and https://www.bustmold.com/montreal/ Timelapse of 3d print here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aO9tmPIGQPU

Tested on Replicator 2.
Works perfectly at basic settings:
Quality: Medium
Infill: 20%
Number of Shells: 2

title: 4 Channel Relay Solid Mount Snug & Snap Fit

description.text:
Snap-In Fit & Snug-Fit
This is a Relay Module with dimensions: L 53.94mm x W 72.93mm
Sorry I forgot the holes on snug version. But snap fit has holes ready!
Snap In Fit and flush mount
I also made this so that it can fit ~ 6mm Length screws. (board mount)
Lightweight & Strong Base Support! I used Fusion 360 to design this project. It was hard working with the vectors to get it working right for the tabs. But I accomplished what I had visioned. Then my slicing software is slic3r currently. I keep my settings low. Then you get a strong durable part! I also am planning on taking this project even further and adding in support for cable tie attachment for cable management! I hope you guys enjoy and use this!

comments.text: I made it using 0.15 layer height, 0.4 shell thickness, 20%, with support. Unfortunately, the hinge three of the hinge post snapped off while I was cleaning off loose threads.  So I repaired the hinges with small nails, and it articulates fine now. But I think its still a bit fragile. I think I need much higher fill.
comments.author: michaelp2016

comments.text: Yeah, the hinges are definitely a bit fragile.  I can try designing another one with stronger hinges.  Frankly, the flexagon is not as interesting a fidget toy as the cube, so I haven't put much effort in.
comments.author: michaelp2016

comments.text: I built your cube too - very nice. I still like this one though. The same kind of hinges would be cool.
comments.author: pkobayashi

comments.text: Could the model be positioned so that bottom faces lie flat on the print bed?
comments.author: thehans

comments.text: Not really? The way the pieces move, there's no position where they're all flat on one plane.  You could certainly get it closer to flat, but it likely wouldn't print well, and figuring out the angles to rotate all the pieces: non trivial!
comments.author: thehans

comments.text: Do you have any recommended print settings for this?
comments.author: munrafd

comments.text: With as much detail as you can get!  I printed at .15mm layer height, so something around there should be the ballpark.  You don't need much fill, but the more you add, the heavier and nicer it feels.
comments.author: munrafd

comments.text: I'll give it a try!  What about supports / rafts?
comments.author: pkobayashi

comments.text: Supports you'll almost definitely need.  If you're printing on glass, you could probably do without the raft.
comments.author: munrafd

comments.text: Ok I'll see how it comes out thanks again!
comments.author: pkobayashi

This is a camera clip for the carriage of the FlashForge Dreamer.  It may fit other models, but only if the carriage has similar construction.
To install the clip, just insert the top and wiggle it downward.  The bottom will eventually snap in under the carriage.  
The clip allows you to use the other parts to attach an inspection endoscope.  I used this one from Amazon, for under $20:
JZHY 1.5m/4.92ft Long Android Smartphone USB Endoscope Inspection Camera, 5.5mm Diameter 6 LEDs HD 720P IP67 Waterproof Snake Borescope
Insert the camera through the camera socket part.  Then screw on the sideview mirror.  Tighten everything up and secure the line to follow your wire loom.  
To get a proper view, you will most likely have to use software that will rotate the image, because the camera will be on its side.  
You can broadcast this to your smartphone using Webcam XP Free.  Then you can monitor your prints remotely, with a detailed view.
I have included "blank" versions of the parts, without the "ball", so that you can add other accessories to them easily.

comments.text: It isn't real long but I didn't want to risk damaging the CD player.  I took my holder and went for a spirited ride in my 6 speed stiff suspension fun car.  It stayed put fine.  It did however have some height (phone) issues.  My fun car has the CD player mounted pretty high.  With this holder it caused the phone to interfere with a part of the dash that extended over the console. It did work and stayed put but I'm not sure I'd want to use it daily because of the dash issue.  (This was designed for the other car.)   I'd suggest holding your phone in landscape mode with the bottom edge even with the CD slot and how that works with your console..  The bottom edge of the phone will be pretty much even with the CD slot.  Let me know how it goes and if I can modify the design for it to work just let me know.   I don't think the length of the CD slot portion will cause you any issues though.  Hopefully anyone else who made this may chime in too.

title: ZMR QAV 250 Uni-Spacer 14,18 & 20mm - For 4mm and 3mm arms

description.text:
Remix of Alexnovik. I wanted a 14mm high vs the 10mm uploaded.
Wanted to be able to fit my CC3D and Orangerx TX into it. The 10mm would of worked but a very tight squeeze. I just added on 4mm more for some "breathing" room. Also filled in the USB opening as my cc3d atom doesn't quite line up with it. Note: Print the XT60 matching connector from his files.
Made modification in SketchUp. Sketchup lessons from BDan. Now with 3mm arms option as well.
Now with 18mm height and 4mm arms.
Now with 20mm height and 3 and 4mm arms Thanks again to Alexnovik. edit #2: Printed the 3mm arms in Green. See images.
Got me thinking, why not print height to about 18mm, this will enable me to have lots of room for the x4 esc, cc3d, orangerx tx, am using a Diatone bottom plate which has PCB built in so room is saved, and vtx.
So this will be a thin one layer ZMR250. Only thing on top would be battery and FPV camera. This will be so clean looking as all wires will be hidden withing the spacer. Will modify one for trial and let you guys know. edit #3: Printed a 20mm version. Everything should fit inside this monstrous cavern. 4 full size escs stacked on top of each other side by side, orangerx RX, cc3d atom. VTX to be mounted in back with camera in front. Battery in the middle. This way I can eliminate the top plate all together. At least that's the goal. May need to print a camera protector just in case of crash. PS: Printed this 3mm version at 100% infill and its pretty solid, much more so than the RED color I printed earlier at 20% infill and less prone to twist. However, since this is only a spacer, not a lot of strength is really needed and weight is of essence. edit for spelling.

title: FUNCTIONAL buckle for IKEA laptop backpack

description.text:
This is a FUNCTIONAL replacement buckle for the Ikea UPPTÄCKA laptop backpack for those that have broke. This is by far my most impressive print, as I proudly display it on my backpack everywhere I go.
If you are looking for the nonfunctional replica or the Ikea design, it's in my designs library :) (The design is too weak for ABS plastic.)

Printer:

XYZ Printing DaVinci 1.0A

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 microns or lower

Infill:

25% minimum

Notes: Print the upper and lower buckles separately! I've tried doing it at the same time. Doing it separately saves you from tearing out your hair.

In General The refining of the lower buckle requires patience.
  • Remove the supports from the slots of the upper and lower buckle
  • File down any visible remnants of the supports
  • Carefully remove the supports from the holes of the lower buckle, careful not to break it. Use something thin and abrasive to get in all the little hard-to-reach corners
  • Sand the rod so that the face of the rod is a rounded square
    • FOR PLA USERS Since PLA is less flexible, the lower part of the buckle may not flex properly. The buckle will still work, but you're limited to a friction-based buckle rather than a snapping buckle. You will need to sand/ file down the teeth of the lower buckle a little <h1> Assembly </h1> For the Upper part of the buckle, loop the belt through the top slot from the rear, then through the bottom slot from the front. Loop the belt through the middle slot from the rear Then loop the belt through the top slot from the front. Done! How to assemble the lower part of the buckle: Slide rod in through the loop Done

<hl2> My existing Ikea backpack broke! </hl2> With all the weight of your backpack on 1 cubic centimeter of metal on the buckle, the buckle is bound to break eventually. Besides structural integrity, functionality of this buckle also makes no sense. What are the slots for? What's the lever for? I was hoping the buckle would have some sort of mechanical buckle I had yet to figure out, but apparently not. I designed this in ROLBOX, a game similar to Minecraft but with more development freedom since all the games are developed by the community. Since printing a rod as thin at the one in the Ikea buckle is not strong enough, I created a friction loop in the upper buckle to replace the useless lever. Then, in my first fastener design, created the pivoting retainer system, which failed just like the Ikea design anyway. Then, in my second fastener design, created a clip system, which was too stiff in the first version. In the second version, I receded the base around the teeth of the lower buckle so that they would have more flex. This is the current version. Flawed design of the existing IKEA Buckle Various revisions of my buckle

title: Helical Crayford Focuser for Newtonian Telescope

description.text:
The Crayford design allows for fine, smooth adjustment in focus, and doesn't require the focuser tube to have a rack machined into it, so it's ideal for ATM's. The helical Crayford looks like it would be a bit easier to print, so designed this one first. Spinning the focuser tube moves the eyepiece in and out, like a telephoto camera lens. Nov 4 '11- Changed the design significantly. i'll probably put this up as a V2 eventually, but think of it as V1.5 for now. the bearings are attached to 'petals' similar to a camera iris, which are held closed with a large hose clamp.
I still need to add a focus tube lock screw, but check out the new design!

Parts list is preliminary.
Getting a properly sized aluminum tube will be tough. Does anyone know of a good, cheap supply of 1-1/4" (31.75 mm) ID Al tubing is used?
Anyway, I've got an idea for how to keep it tensioned on the tube, so stay tuned.
The mounting plate has more holes than necessary but the idea is that you glue the mounting plate to the optical tube, so i wanted to give extra mounting holes for other types of focuser designs. You'll need to put a m4 nut in each hole of the mounting plate before you glue it down, of course.
You should also glue the eyepiece lock into the focuser tube, but make sure an eyepiece will actually fit first. The holes on the lock are for M3 screws, and they are undersized so the screw self-taps.
The focus lock screw will probably be inconvenient without a knob or handle. it might also be good to have something on the other end of the screw in order to prevent the steel from marring the aluminum. something made out of PTFE would be ideal so that the lock would also be a clutch, adding some friction to the spinning.

title: K3020 Laser Air Assist
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
On the newer K3020 clone of these 40w laser's the back wall is farther forward and the X-End bracket will hit it before the homing switch is reached, also at the head the cable chain will come into contact with the back wall as well so i had to push the cable chain farther forward and shortened and modified the X-End bracket as well as the carriage mounting bracket.  
The laser holder is made to fit a 12mmx30mm laser module, i used one with a cross pattern lense and after printing the laser holder it will be slightly undersized so i warmed up the part with a hot air gun and press fit the laser module into the holder.  Alternatively you could file it out for a snug fit and use a bit of glue, i used a dab of hot glue once the focus on the laser modules lens was adjusted to keep it from rotating and going out of focus.  I also modified the carriage mount for a single side mounted laser module, the original was setup to mount two laser modules for a cross dot setup but using the cross X-Lens version i didn't need that.
The Tab file is optional but if you want a Y-Axis cable chain then it gets glued to the side of the X-End mount, this was done in two parts just for easier printing and its plenty solid after being solvent welded to the other piece.  The other end of the Y-Axis cable chain is just attached to the bottom of the cabinet with some double sided adhesive mounting tape as it doesn't take much if any movement stress.  This gives a nice smooth running location for the air line and laser module power wiring.
I also modified the air tubing hole on the carriage mount to just pass the flexible silicone tubing i used for the air line, acts as a strain relief, and it loops down to the barbed fitting on the air assist nozzle. I used the air assist head from LightObject as its so cheap!!  Just take note that these machines have a 12mm diameter focal lens and the LightObject air assist head uses a 18mm, but there is a design on here for an adapter ring so i printed one of those and re-used my 12mm stock lens and it works great!

Customizable Reuleaux Triangle, Tetrahedron and Solid of revolution. The picture shows the standard Reuleaux triangle used as a keyring.
You can customize features such as: size, side thickness, height etc.
The Reuleaux triangle is unique - it is the simplest shape of constant width after the circle. It's diameter is constant, however it's radius is not - these properties allow it to be used in applications such as drill bits (to cut square holes) and rotary engines. The Reuleaux tetrahedron however is not of constant width (although it is pretty close). Revolving the triangle around it's midpoint will give you an acorn shaped solid of revolution which is also of constant width.

author: markco1000

description.text:
This is a fairly detailed model of an iPhone 4 GSM according to case design specification from apple.com I'm new to openscad, so surely a few hundred things could be done better, and I'm willing to learn so I welcome any feedback. This utilizes the roundedRect function (with modifications) - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9347 - by WilliamAAdams. The model inserted into an openscad iphone dock - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10270 - by jag is shown in one of the images. This shows how you use the model to see if you block any of the phone's features with your design. Planned improvements:
  • setting the color as parameter - to be fixed. Current color RGB[.4,.4,.4] - the 3 screen shots were done before the color was set, so they are the default yellow - DONE
  • Getting suggestions and acting on them... :)
    • The iPhone is copyright of Apple inc. and this design should not be reproduced for any other purpose than allowed by law on copyright and design rights. Please see: http://developer.apple.com/resources/cases/ which is the source of the drawing used. Someone already did this long before me - please look at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3392 by whosawhatsis (Thanks for the message).

title: Bolt-able bracket for a Veho USB Microscope

description.text:
This is a simple, adjustable bracket for Veho USB microscopes. I have tested it with a Veho 400x USB microscope but I beleive it works with the 200x one as well as the Maplin look-alike.  
The bracket was designed by my fellow student, Janik Lam. It was created in Creo Parametric and the two files other than the STL relate to that.   
I have only had this printed out on high end, professional FDM and SLS machines so the fine clip detail might take some inventive remixing of this.  
TODO: Upload pictures of both prints of the bracket
It was printed on an EOS FDM in a high temperature plastic and also on an SLS machine whilst using heavily recycled nylon 12 powder.

title: Sunhokey Prusa i3 Hot End Bracket

description.text: This is the first version of my new hot end bracket for a Sunhokey Prusa i3. Basically the frame is stiffer than the original and has space for an extra SC8UU bearing (they are about $2 each off eBay) which stops the bearings rocking. There are spaces for the GT2 timing belt, hot end fan and bracket, and for both X-axis limit switches. It was designed with minimal filament consumption in mind. A new version that I am developing is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1287974

Printer:

Sunhokey Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.2

Infill:

100% for strength

Notes: Make sure you add support everywhere. It is designed to be printed from it's side. My print was PLA with an ABS slurry to help bed adhesion.

Bearing alignment As when you first built the printer, it is critical that you get the bearings aligned properly so they don't drag and scrape against the smooth rods. First just lightly tighten all the bearings, then jiggle them until their travel is smooth. Tighten each bolt in increments whilst continually testing the smoothness of travel.

author: mattsson81

title: Sunhokey Prusa i3 Hot End Bracket V2

description.text:
This is the second version of my new hot end bracket for a Sunhokey Prusa i3. I have not tested this part yet so there could still be issues.
Basically the frame is stiffer than the original and has space for an extra SC8UU bearing (they are about $2 each off eBay) which stops the bearings rocking.
Version 2 has room for two extra fans (although I have not modelled the attachments yet). It also has extra support for the hot end.
There are spaces for the GT2 timing belt, hot end fan and bracket, and for both X-axis limit switches.
It was designed with minimal filament consumption in mind.

Printer:

Sunhokey Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100% for strength

Notes: Make sure you add support everywhere. It is designed to be printed from it's side. My print was PLA with an ABS slurry to help bed adhesion.

Bearing alignment As when you first built the printer, it is critical that you get the bearings aligned properly so they don't drag and scrape against the smooth rods. First just lightly tighten all the bearings, then jiggle them until their travel is smooth. Tighten each bolt in increments whilst continually testing the smoothness of travel.
